column1: #Text=Stoichiometric FeGe was melted, using induction heating and, to guarantee homogeneity, re-melted twice and annealed for 130 h at 1000 K.
#Text=Cylinders were formed and a high pressure high temperature synthesis inside a Kawai-type30 multianvil apparatus with Walker-type31 module was applied.
#Text=This resulted in 95% polycrystalline B20 FeGe, confirmed by X-ray diffraction.
#Text=A maximum of 5% of the sample material could consist of secondary phase Iron Germanium.
#Text=Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) measurements also reveal local composition variations with accumulation of iron (Fe:Ge 55:45).
#Text=Further investigations with Lorentz microscopy show the formation of helices and skyrmions (Fig. 1(a)) in accordance to32.

#Text=Micron sized samples (Fig. 1(b)) with wedge shaped geometries were cut using a Focused Ion Beam (FIB – FEI Helios nanolab 600) and placed inside an R-Type microresonator33–35 using standard lift-off FIB (Omniprobe manipulator with Pt gas insertion system) technique.
#Text=During the lift-off process a carbon coating with up to 100 nm thickness and up to 15% platinum contamination36 could not be avoided.
#Text=Furthermore, the lift-off process used Gallium as cutting ions and resulted in a localized deposition of a maximum of 2.6% of Ga (as verified by EDX).
